oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Asbury Methodist: front view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of church front and side yard. Facade of church features front steps with handrails, double front doors, transom window, and two-over-two sash window. Gable vent overlaying a cross emblem appears above the gabled roof of the porch. Side awning shelters the entrance to the basement level. Road appears to the side of the church. The Green McAdoo Cultural Center sits atop the hill in the background.

Set originally in a Civil War-era log structure, the Asbury United Methodist Church was called Tate's Chapel after the first pastor, Rev. John C. Tate. A former slave, Tate gained prominence in Anderson County and was elected the clerk of the Circuit Court. The church was founded by a community of freed slaves on Foley's Hill in Clinton, TN during Reconstruction and they appointed Tate as pastor; his name adorned the log church's cornerstone. Officially established on May 29, 1865, the church steadily gained membership, necessitating the construction of a new church. Once again, the church acquired a name from a church official. Dubbed the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, the new church building survived until a fire in 1947. The third and current brick building was finished in 1950.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee;
churches; steeples; chimneys; sash windows; transom windows;
